Chapter 8, Part 2: Distinguishing Cognition, in what stage does one suddenly cultivate how many cognitions?
First, one should contemplate and discern, what is called cultivation?
It means cultivating and perfecting the conditioned good, making it freely effective.
Not defiled or indeterminate, because there is no superior loved result.
Not good or unconditioned, because it is not in the continuity, and also because the unconditioned has no result.
Having distinguished the meaning of cultivation, the original question should be answered.
First, in the fifteen minds of the path of seeing, the verse says:
In the path of seeing, when forbearance and cognition arise, one cultivates those in the future.
In the three categories of cognition, one also cultivates the conventional cognition at the end of the realization of the truth.
One does not generate [cognition] in one's own or lower stages, and in the four of suffering and accumulation, after cessation.
The objects of one's own truth and aspects are only attained through added effort.
The treatise says:

In the state of the path of insight, whether one produces the class of perseverance or the class of knowledge, one cultivates in the future the class of perseverance or the class of knowledge. However, one cultivates the aspects and the mindfulness of the truths.
Why is it that the path of insight cultivates only the same species?
Because the object of activity and the object-support are both fixed and different.

There is an interpretation that this is because this species was not previously acquired. Therefore, when the three subsequent knowledges of suffering, the origin of suffering, and the path are present, one is able to cultivate the conventional knowledge of the path of insight in the future.
Because one is able to cultivate it at the end of the vision of each truth, it is given this name.
For this reason, in other states one is not yet able to cultivate it, because the task of each truth is not yet complete.
There is an interpretation that

if one cultivates it in the state of knowledge of the law, it should be called conventional knowledge in the path of insight, and the scriptures should not establish the name knowledge of the end of the path of insight.
What is superior and what is inferior in the three states of cultivation?
If we consider the continuity of the three states, the latter is superior to the former, because one obtains it by arousing the body that is nourished by the cause.
If we consider the realm, the higher is superior to the lower.
Therefore, the bonds of the form realm cultivated previously are superior in realm but inferior in body.
The bonds of the desire realm cultivated in the later stage are inferior in realm but superior in body.
There are four alternatives here, which should be considered in accordance with reason.
Why is this not cultivated at the time of the knowledge of the species of the path?
This knowledge is only an associate of the path of insight. Since it is included in the path of cultivation, it cannot be cultivated.
This means that the cultivation of the seven good factors is the seed, and the path of insight is born from it. Therefore, when the path of insight is born, it is said that they are associates.
Or, mundane knowledge, from beginningless time, has known, eliminated, and realized the three truths, but has never cultivated the path. Therefore, it is not cultivated now.
Or, because one now sees the true path, the false path is ashamed and avoided, and therefore it is not cultivated.
Or, this knowledge is cultivated only at the edge of realization. Since the path is boundless, it is not cultivated in this stage.

That is, in the three truths, one who relies on the contemplation of phenomena may obtain the limit of one aspect, but there is no one who can cultivate the path everywhere, because the path of different natures cannot be cultivated.
Although one may be able to cultivate within one's own nature, it is like a hundred thousand parts, not arising as one.

Although in the stage of the path of insight one has not yet completely eliminated the aggregates and has not yet completely realized cessation, in the present stage the elimination of the aggregates and the realization of cessation are already complete.

At the time of the knowledge of the species of the path, the counteragent to the delusion that is confused about the truth of the path is also not cultivated everywhere, because the species and faculties are of many classes.
For this reason, the World Honored One spoke of the limit in the three truths.
As a scripture says, there is the limit of the body, there is the limit of the arising of the body, and there is the limit of the cessation of the body.
There has never been a scripture that says there is the limit of the path of the body, because there is no one who can cultivate the path to the limit.
This conventional knowledge is a dharma that does not arise, because it is not possible to give rise to it at any time, and because the body on which it depends definitely does not arise.

That is, the body of one who practices according to faith or according to the Dharma may be the support for the arising of this knowledge, but it is impossible for it to arise in the state of the path of insight.
Therefore this body is not born and does not arise, and because the support does not arise, this knowledge certainly does not arise.
If this is so, on what basis does one speak of the meaning of cultivation?
It is called cultivation because one cultivates the acquisition of this knowledge.

That is, at that time one acquires mastery over its arising, but because other conditions are lacking, its substance does not appear. It is said that one acquires it because one acquires mastery over its arising.

There are dharmas that are acquired and then appear, such as the knowledge of the exhaustion of the contaminants.ğŸ”½There are dharmas that are first acquired and then appear, such as the knowledge of nonproduction.
There are dharmas that are acquired but never appear, such as this knowledge of extinction.
There are dharmas that appear without being acquired, such as external form.
There are no dharmas that are not living beings that appear without being acquired. Therefore, although this knowledge does not arise, there is the meaning of cultivation.
When the path of insight is present in any stage, how many future paths of insight and conventional knowledges can it cultivate?
This conventional knowledge is supported on seven stages, namely, the preliminary stage, intermediate stage, four meditations, and the realm of desire.
If the path of insight is present in the preliminary stage, it can cultivate one future path of insight and two conventional knowledges.
Up to when the path of insight is present in the fourth meditation, it can cultivate six future paths of insight and seven conventional knowledges.

When cultivated at the end of the path of insight into the truths of suffering and origination, it is included in the four foundations of mindfulness. When cultivated at the end of the path of insight into the truth of cessation, it is only the foundation of mindfulness of dharmas.
According to which truth one cultivates at the end of the path of insight, one takes that aspect and takes that truth as object.

If one cultivates at the end of the path of insight into the truth of suffering, one takes the four aspects of the truth of suffering as object. If it is associated with the realm of desire, one takes the suffering of the realm of desire as object. If it is associated with the realm of form, one takes the suffering of the upper truths as object.

If one cultivates at the edge of the realization of the truth of accumulation, then one uses the four aspects of taking accumulation as objects. If it is bound to the desire realm, it takes the accumulation of the desire realm as objects. If it is bound to the form realm, it takes the accumulation of the upper realms as objects.

If one cultivates at the edge of the realization of the truth of cessation, then one uses the four aspects of taking cessation as objects. If it is bound to the desire realm, it takes the cessation of the desire realm as objects. If it is bound to the form realm, it takes the cessation of the upper realms as objects.
This conventional knowledge is only attained through added effort, because it is attained through the added effort of the path of seeing.

That which is included in the desire realm is accomplished through volition. That which is included in the form realm is accomplished through cultivation. It is not accomplished through hearing, because it is weak.

Because of the increase of knowledge, it is established as the name of knowledge. If it is accompanied by its associates, it takes the four aggregates of the desire realm and the five aggregates of the form realm as its intrinsic nature.
Next, in the stage of detachment in the path of cultivation, a verse says:
In the first moment of the path of cultivation, one cultivates six or seven knowledges.
In the uninterrupted stage of severing the eight grounds, and in the remaining paths of those with desire,
The summit of existence and the eight liberations each cultivate seven knowledges.
Above, in the uninterrupted path and other paths, they cultivate six and eight respectively.
The treatise says:

The first moment of cultivation is at the time of the sixteenth knowledge of the path and its aspects. Two knowledges are presently cultivated, namely the knowledge of the path and the knowledge of the path and its aspects, which are distinguished by name but not by substance.

One who has not yet abandoned desire cultivates six in the future, namely the knowledge of dharmas, the knowledge of species, the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of the cause of suffering, the knowledge of the cessation of suffering, and the knowledge of the path.
One who has abandoned desire cultivates seven, namely adding the knowledge of others' minds, because it is the antidote to the summit of existence.
One does not cultivate conventional knowledge, because one has already abandoned desire beforehand.
For what reason does one who has entered the noble path not cultivate the knowledge of others' minds in the path of insight?
Because the knowledge of others' minds is included in the category of meditative observation, and there is the meaning of cultivation only in dependence on the path of ease.
In the stage of the path of insight, in order to contemplate the principles of the truths, the practice is extremely rapid, and therefore one is not able to cultivate it.
The meaning in the uninterrupted path is also the same as this.
Now, at the time of the sixteenth knowledge of the path and its aspects, it is included in the path of ease, and therefore one cultivates this knowledge.

In the nine uninterrupted paths and eight liberation paths that eliminate the passions to be eliminated by cultivation in the realm of desire, four conventional knowledges and four knowledges of dharmas are actualized as appropriate.
In the uninterrupted paths that eliminate the seven stages above, four conventional knowledges, four subsequent knowledges, and knowledges of cessation and path are actualized as appropriate.
In the paths of preparation and advancement in the realm of desire, four conventional knowledges and four subsequent knowledges are actualized as appropriate.

In the future, one cultivates seven knowledges, namely, conventional knowledge, knowledge of dharmas, subsequent knowledge, knowledge of suffering, knowledge of the origin of suffering, knowledge of cessation, and knowledge of the path.
In the first eight liberation paths that eliminate the stage of the summit of existence, four subsequent knowledges, two knowledges of dharmas, and as appropriate, are actualized.

In the future, one also cultivates only seven, but excluding conventional knowledge, adding knowledge of others' minds.ğŸ”½In the nine uninterrupted paths that eliminate the stage of the summit of existence, four subsequent knowledges, two knowledges of dharmas, and as appropriate, are actualized. In the future, one cultivates the six knowledges of dharmas, subsequent knowledges, knowledge of suffering, knowledge of the origin of suffering, knowledge of cessation, and knowledge of the path.

In the ninth liberation path that eliminates the passions to be eliminated by cultivation in the realm of desire, four conventional knowledges and four knowledges of dharmas are actualized as appropriate.

The four conventional knowledges, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path are cultivated in the present in accordance with the circumstances in the path of liberation that cuts off the seven stages above.

The ninth path of advancement that cuts off the desire realm is cultivated in the present.ğŸ”½The four conventional knowledges, the knowledge of suffering and its origin, and the knowledge of cessation and the path are cultivated in the present in accordance with the circumstances in the path of added effort that cuts off the eight stages above.

The four conventional knowledges, the knowledge of suffering and its origin, the knowledge of cessation and the path, and the knowledge of others' minds are cultivated in the present in accordance with the circumstances in the path of advancement that cuts off the eight stages of the peak of existence above. This is because the previously cultivated conventional knowledge is able to appear.

Above this, eight knowledges are cultivated in the future, namely, the conventional, the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of its origin, the knowledge of cessation, the knowledge of the path, the knowledge of others' minds, and the knowledge of destruetion.

The two knowledges of suffering and its origin of the realm of desire are not able to cut off the passions of the realm of desire. The two knowledges of suffering and its origin are not the antidote of the higher stages. What is the reason for producing them as antidotes?
These two knowledges are cultivated in the future.

If it is admitted that one cultivates the antidote and that which is not the antidote, then one should cultivate the conventional knowledge in the future when one is free from the passions of the peak of existence.
This objection is unreasonable, because only the same antidote is cultivated in the future, and this is not admitted.

That is, one cultivates the conventional knowledge of the path of insight because it is related to the path of insight. Or, one cultivates it by the power of causes, as when one eliminates desire and cultivates the four categories of knowledge. When one eliminates the passions of the upper realms, one cultivates the knowledge of the truth of suffering and the knowledge of the truth of the origination of suffering.

If one eliminates the passions of the realm of desire but does not cultivate the knowledge of the species, and if one eliminates the passions of the upper realms but does not cultivate the knowledge of suffering and the knowledge of the truth of the origination of suffering, then one who gradually attains the fruit of nonreturner would not be able to manifest the knowledge of the species. An arhat would not be able to manifest the knowledge of suffering and the knowledge of the truth of the origination of suffering, because he would have already eliminated that which he had previously acquired, and that which he had not previously acquired would not be that which he cultivates.

It is by species that if one has already acquired it previously, it becomes the power of a similar cause and attracts the knowledge that flows from it. This knowledge is attracted by that previous knowledge and in turn can be a cause for that knowledge.
Therefore, when this knowledge is born, the power of the cause aids it, and even though it is not the same antidote, it is cultivated in the future.
Next, we distinguish the acquisition of the state of post-learner through the elimination of passion.
A verse says:
In the first moment of the stage of no-more-learning, one cultivates nine or ten knowledges,
Because of the distinction of dull faculties and sharp faculties. The same is true for the path of advancement.
The treatise says:

The first moment of the stage of no-more-learning refers to the ninth liberation that eliminates the peak of existence. The extinction of the categories of suffering and accumulation are manifested according to circumstances. Because it takes the peak of existence as its object, the path of advancement cultivates nine or ten knowledges according to circumstances.

In the future, one cultivates nine or ten knowledges according to circumstances. This refers to those of dull faculties who only eliminate the knowledge of non-arising, while those of sharp faculties also cultivate the knowledge of non-arising.
Next, the cultivation of the quantity of knowledges in other stages is discussed.
In verse it is said:
In the uninterrupted path of cultivating faculties, learners cultivate six [knowledges], and no-more-learners cultivate seven.
In the rest, learners cultivate six, seven, or eight. They should cultivate eight, nine, or all [knowledges].
In the uninterrupted path of mixed cultivation of supernormal powers, learners cultivate seven. They should cultivate eight or nine.
In the rest of the paths, learners cultivate eight. They should cultivate nine or all [knowledges].ğŸ”½The sages give rise to other merits,
And in the stages of ordinary beings,
The amount of wisdom cultivated should all be considered according to reason.
The treatise says:
In the stage of learning, in the uninterrupted paths of the faculties of penetrating insight, the four knowledges of dharmas and kinds are cultivated as appropriate.

In the future, six are cultivated, because the four truths and the knowledge of dharmas and kinds are similar to the path of seeing. The conventional [knowledge] is not cultivated because it can eliminate hindrances and does not cultivate the knowledge of others.
In the paths of liberation, the four knowledges of dharmas and kinds are cultivated as appropriate.
Those who have not yet eliminated desire cultivate six in the future, the four truths and the knowledge of dharmas and kinds.
Those who have already eliminated desire cultivate seven in the future, adding the knowledge of others.
Other masters say:

In the state of the path of liberation, the conventional [knowledge] is also cultivated. In the various paths of preparation, the conventional [knowledge], four knowledges of dharmas and kinds are cultivated as appropriate.
Those who have not yet eliminated desire cultivate seven in the future.
Those who have already eliminated desire cultivate eight in the future, adding the knowledge of others. In the various paths of advancement,
if one has not yet eliminated desire, the conventional [knowledge], four knowledges of dharmas and kinds are cultivated as appropriate. In the future, seven are also cultivated.
If one has already separated from desire, one cultivates four conventional knowledges, four knowledges of other minds, and four Dharma knowledges in the present, and also eight in the future.
In the uninterrupted paths of the faculties of the adept, one cultivates four Dharma knowledges and two subsequent knowledges in the present, and seven in the future.
In the path of insight, one does not cultivate conventional knowledge, just as one does not cultivate the knowledge of the path of insight in the summit of existence.

In the first eight liberations, one cultivates four Dharma knowledges and two subsequent knowledges in the present, and eight in the future.ğŸ”½In the ninth liberation, one cultivates four Dharma knowledges, four subsequent knowledges, and the knowledge of the destruction of the outflows in the present, and eight in the future.
In the last liberation, one cultivates four Dharma knowledges, four subsequent knowledges, and the knowledge of the destruction of the outflows in the present, and ten in the future.
In the preparatory paths, one cultivates as in the path of insight in the present, and nine in the future.
In the paths of advancement, the dull person cultivates nine knowledges in the present as appropriate, and also nine in the future.
The sharp person cultivates ten knowledges in the present as appropriate, and also ten in the future.

In the stage of learning, in the uninterrupted paths of mixed cultivation, one cultivates the four of Dharma and non-dharma, conventional, and as appropriate, in the present. In the future, one cultivates seven.
In the paths of liberation, one only cultivates the four of Dharma and non-dharma. In the preparatory paths, one increases conventional [cognition].
In the paths of advancement, one also cultivates the cognition of others' minds as appropriate in the present. In the future, one cultivates all eight.

In the stage of no-more-learning, in the uninterrupted paths of mixed cultivation, one cultivates in the present as in the stage of learning. In the future, one cultivates the dull eight and sharp nine.
In the paths of liberation, one only cultivates the four of Dharma and non-dharma.
In the preparatory paths, one increases conventional [cognition]. As appropriate, one cultivates in the present.
In the future, one cultivates the dull nine and sharp ten.
The paths of advancement are the same as the training in faculties.
In the stage of learning, in the five uninterrupted paths of cultivating spiritual powers, one cultivates conventional cognition in the present. In the future, one cultivates seven.
In the two paths of liberation of supernormal knowledge and spiritual powers, and in the five preparatory paths, one cultivates conventional cognition in the present.

In the liberation of the cognition of others' minds, one cultivates the cognition of Dharma, non-dharma, path, conventional, and others' minds. In all paths of advancement, and in the cessation of suffering and accumulation as appropriate, one cultivates in the present.
Above this, in the future, one cultivates eight knowledges.
In the five uninterrupted paths of cultivation of the adept, one presently cultivates as in the learning stage, and in the future one cultivates eight dull and nine sharp.
In the paths of liberation and added effort, one presently cultivates as in the learning stage, and in the future one cultivates nine dull and ten sharp.
The paths of added effort are the same as the paths of added effort in the stage of preparation for the realization of the fruit of arhatship.
The two paths of liberation of the divine eye and divine ear are not called cultivation because they are of indeterminate nature.

When the holy one produces the remaining four immeasurables, etc., which are included in the category of cultivation, when they are impure qualities, in the present he cultivates the worldly knowledge of the path.
In the future, the learner who has not yet eliminated desire cultivates seven, and the one who has eliminated desire cultivates eight.
The adept in the future cultivates nine dull and ten sharp, excluding the mind of slight and slight. This is because in the future one only cultivates worldly knowledge.

If one produces the remaining impure qualities, those included in the category of dhyÄna, one presently cultivates the four knowledges of dharmas, inferential, extinction, and no more rebirth, as appropriate.
Those included in the category of formlessness, one presently cultivates only the four inferential knowledges, as appropriate.
The same is true of the future cultivation of the same as the previous contaminated [path].

Ordinary beings who are free from desire, presently cultivating worldly cognition, abandoning the three concentrations of desire, the ninth liberation, and relying on the fundamental four concentrations to give rise to the path of progress, the practice of abandoning desire,
in the future cultivate two, namely adding the cognition of others' minds. The rest in the future only cultivate the worldly [cognition].

When cultivating the five supernatural powers, in the preparatory paths and two paths of liberation, one presently cultivates worldly cognition. In one path of liberation, one presently manifests the worldly cognition of others' minds.
In the paths of progress, the two [cognitions] are manifested as appropriate. In the future, all cultivate the two kinds.
In the five uninterrupted paths, the present and future are only worldly.
Relying on the fundamental concentrations to cultivate the remaining merits, all presently cultivate the worldly [cognition], and in the future cultivate the two [cognitions].
Only the factors conducive to penetration necessarily do not cultivate the cognition of others' minds, because it is the proximate retinue of the path of seeing.
Relying on the concentrations of other stages to cultivate the remaining merits, all only presently and in the future cultivate the worldly [cognition].
How many stages are cultivated in the future?
Are all attainments of arising the cultivation of that?
Verse:
The paths rely on this and attain this, cultivating the contaminated dharmas of this stage.
In order to be free from attaining this, cultivating this and the contaminated dharmas below.
Only the first exhaustion universally cultivates the contaminated virtues of the nine stages.
Being born above, not cultivating below, what has been attained before is not cultivation.
The treatise says:

The paths rely on this stage and attain this stage, being able to cultivate the future contaminated dharmas of this stage. This means that when the worldly and noble paths of this stage are present, only the contaminated dharmas of this stage are cultivated in the future. This is because contaminated dharmas are firmly bound to the stage and difficult to cultivate in other stages. According to which stage one relies on to be free from the contamination of the lower stages,

when the ninth liberation is present, one also cultivates the future contaminated virtues of the fundamental and proximate stages above that which have been attained. This is because being free from the bonds of the lower stages necessarily obtains the upper stages.

When one becomes a sage and is free from this stage and obtains this stage, and when the various paths of this stage are present, one is able to cultivate this stage and the undefiled of lower stages.

That is to say, when the path of preparation, etc., of any stage, whether impure or pure, is present, in order to eliminate the passions of this stage, one cultivates in the future this stage and the undefiled of lower stages, because the lower stages are able to eliminate the passions of the higher stages.

Even though the lower holy paths eliminate passions, the higher stages are able to eliminate them in the same way, but because the stages of the impure realm are firmly attached, one is not yet able to cultivate them before one is free from the lower stages.
There is an opinion that one also cultivates the higher stages, because one produces and obtains the elimination of the passions of the higher stages.

According to which stage one is able to be free from the passions of the lower stages, when the ninth liberation is present, one also cultivates in the future the pure qualities of the higher stages that one has obtained and of the lower stages.
When the worldly and holy paths of this stage are present, in the future one cultivates all the pure qualities of this stage and the lower stages.

Only when the first knowledge of exhaustion is present can one cultivate all the immeasurable excellent qualities of the stage of thought of the impure contemplation, etc., which are included in the stage of thought of the realm of desire, and which are accomplished by hearing, reflection, and cultivation.
That is, according to the stage in which the knowledge of exhaustion is present, one cultivates in the future the higher and lower stages.
Why is it that only at the time of the first knowledge of exhaustion can one cultivate all the contaminated qualities?
Because it is able to destroy for the first time the enemy, the passions, which are the roots of all good dharmas since beginningless time.
It is like the case of a universal monarch who subdues the common enemy of the state; all come to rejoice and praise him.
Also, because the bonds of the passions are eliminated without remainder, it is like the case of the bonds that bind being eliminated and the bound person is able to move freely.
Also, the king of the mind ascends the position of sovereignty, and all good dharmas come to pay homage.
It is like the case of a great king who ascends the throne and is anointed, and all the lands come to pay tribute.
However, if one is born in a higher stage, one certainly does not cultivate the lower stages.

That is, when the body is in the realm of desire and one obtains the state of arhat, one cultivates the wholesome roots of the nine stages of the three realms. When one is born in the peak of existence, one only cultivates one stage.

The first word extinction shows that one abandons the previous path in the ninth liberated path of the five faculties of separation from the peak of existence and the training. Because one newly obtains the fruit.

In the stage of the path of insight, although one can also cultivate the worldly cognition of oneself and below at the end of the three kinds of cognition, because it has already been explained, it is not discussed here.
All that is said to be cultivated is only what was not previously obtained but is now produced and now obtained.
This is what is cultivated.
That is, if it was not obtained before but is now obtained through effort, it is then what is cultivated.
If a dharma was previously obtained but then abandoned, although it is now obtained again, it is not what is cultivated, because it is not obtained through exertion.
If it was not obtained before but is produced, it is produced through great effort, because its power is superior. Only then can it cultivate future merits.

If one has already obtained it and now manifests it, one cannot cultivate future merits, because it is not produced by much effort, its power is weak, and the function of cultivation ceases, so one cannot cultivate future [merits].
If one who has already obtained and manifested it can cultivate future [merits], then when the Blessed One attained the knowledge of exhaustion, he should not have yet fully cultivated all merits.

In order to fully realize and attain, he should further cultivate [merits], and then he would be the same as the two vehicles whose merits are not yet full. Is it only based on attainment that it is called cultivation?ğŸ”½No.
What is it then?
There are four kinds of cultivation: 1. cultivation of attainment, 2. cultivation of practice, 3. cultivation of counteraction, and 4. cultivation of elimination.
On what dharmas are these four cultivations established?
The verse says:
The cultivation of attainment and the cultivation of practice are established based on conditioned good dharmas.
The cultivation of elimination and the cultivation of counteraction are established based on all contaminated dharmas.
The treatise says:
All previously acquired and all previously unacquired merits that are present, as well as future merits that are acquired through mixed cultivation, are all called cultivation as acquisition.
All previously acquired and previously unacquired merits that are present, because they are cultivated through present practice, are all called cultivation as practice.
These two are established only on the basis of conditioned good dharmas.

Only future dharmas are called cultivation as acquisition, and only present dharmas are endowed with both kinds of cultivation. When one acquires the antidote to the body, etc., it is called cultivation of the antidotes to the body, etc.
Therefore, when one acquires the antidotes to the body, etc., it is said that one cultivates the body, etc.
The same principle holds for the other impure dharmas.ğŸ”½When the passions that take the body, etc., as objects are eliminated, the body, etc., are called cultivated through elimination.
Therefore, when the passions that take the body, etc., as objects are eliminated, it is said that one cultivates the body, etc.
The same principle holds for the other impure dharmas.
These two are established only on the basis of impure dharmas, and therefore impure good dharmas are endowed with all four kinds of cultivation.
Uncontaminated conditioned dharmas and other contaminated dharmas possess the latter two kinds of cultivation, respectively.
There is a distinction of dharmas possessing more or less cultivation in terms of future cultivation.
There are dharmas possessing four kinds of cultivation, there are dharmas possessing three, there are dharmas possessing two, there are dharmas possessing one, and there are dharmas possessing none.
That is, when wholesome contaminated dharmas have not yet been permanently eliminated, they can be obtained and produced, and they possess all four kinds of cultivation.

Because they have not yet been permanently eliminated, they will possess the cultivation of elimination in the future. Because they can be obtained, they will possess the cultivation of obtaining in the future. Because they can be produced, they will possess the cultivation of practice in the future.
Those that have been obtained and can be produced possess three, excluding the cultivation of obtaining and the cultivation of obtaining that can be obtained.
Those that cannot be produced possess three, excluding the cultivation of practice, the cultivation of obtaining that has been obtained, and the cultivation of obtaining that cannot be obtained.
Those that have already been produced possess two, namely the cultivation of elimination and the cultivation of elimination of contaminated and indeterminate dharmas.
Those that have not yet been eliminated are also like this.

If one obtains and produces good impure dharmas when they have been eternally eliminated, one obtains both the possession of the present and the possession of the future. One may obtain but not produce them, possessing only the possession of the future. One may obtain and produce them, possessing both the possession of the present and the future.
Know that conditioned pure dharmas are also like this.
All the rest are completely nonexistent, i.e., pure dharmas that have been obtained but are not produced, etc.

If dharmas that are not produced do not reside in the body, but one is said to cultivate them merely by obtaining them, then you must admit that cessation resulting from discrimination is also cultivation, because there is no difference.
This objection is unreasonable, because those dharmas of the same species reside in the body.
That is, although dharmas that are not produced do not reside in the body, it is not a mistake to say that one cultivates them by the residence in the body of dharmas of the same species.

Also, because they reside as results of the possession of the possession. That is, good dharmas that are not produced in the future are caused to be produced by the possession of the possession, which is revealed as their result.
We say that we do not produce them because of the absence of conditions, not that we do not now receive their attraction.
Cessation resulting from discrimination is different from this and cannot be used as an analogy.
Also, future wholesome dharmas that are not yet born also have the power of causes to benefit the present body.
Extinction through discrimination is not like this, and therefore there is no meaning of cultivation.

Also, because extinction through discrimination is only a result, that is, cultivation is originally for the sake of obtaining superior results. Extinction is not a result, and therefore it should not be cultivated.
Also, because extinction through discrimination has no increase or decrease, that is, cultivable dharmas rely on the lower to reach the middle, and rely on the middle to reach the superior.
Extinction through discrimination is not like this, and has no use in cultivation, and therefore it cannot be cultivated.
Thus far, the distinctions of various knowledges have been explained. The merits accomplished by knowledge will now be revealed.
Among them, first the unique qualities of a Buddha are distinguished.
When a Buddha first attains enlightenment and reaches the stage of the knowledge of exhaustion, he cultivates the eighteen kinds of unique qualities of a Buddha.
What are the eighteen?
The verse says:
The eighteen unique qualities of a Buddha are the ten powers, etc.
The treatise says:
The ten powers of a buddha, the four forms of fearlessness, the three foundations of mindfulness, and great compassion, these combined are called the eighteen distinctive abilities of a buddha.
Only at the time of the knowledge of termination do buddhas cultivate these; they are not possessed by other saints, and therefore they are called distinctive.
What are the differences among the ten powers of a buddha?
Verse:
The ten powers are: knowledge of proper conditions and improper conditions, knowledge of actions, knowledge of the eight liberations,
knowledge of the nine categories of faculties, knowledge of the various aspirations, knowledge of the paths that lead everywhere,
knowledge of the four knowledges of termination, knowledge of past abodes, knowledge of future destinies, and knowledge of the extinction of contamination.
The knowledge of past abodes and knowledge of future destinies are based on the dhyanas, the others are universal.
In Jambudvipa, male, in the body of a buddha, unobstructed with regard to objects.
Commentary:

The ten powers of a buddha are: the power of knowledge of proper conditions and improper conditions, which is by nature endowed with the ten knowledges of a tathagata. Knowing that the nature and function of all dharmas is definitely existent is called the knowledge of proper conditions;
knowing that the nature and function of all dharmas is definitely nonexistent is called the knowledge of improper conditions.
This knowledge is capable of taking as objects both sentient beings and nonsentient beings, and it is not in contradiction to any of the other ten knowledges.
Fearing that it would be difficult to understand the ten knowledges in such a brief explanation, the author has analyzed them here into the other ten powers.

The power of knowledge of the retribution of actions is composed of eight knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path, that is, unobstructed knowledge that distinguishes the retribution of various kinds of actions and the various kinds of results of retribution.

It is also called the power of knowledge of oneâ€™s own actions, that is, unobstructed knowledge that distinguishes the kind of result that is received through the power of oneâ€™s own actions and that cannot be given or taken away by wife, children, etc., and the kind of action that necessarily produces oneâ€™s own result and cannot be traded for the results of other actions.

The power of knowledge of the various meditations, liberations, samÄdhis, and samÄpattis; the power of knowledge of superior and inferior faculties; the power of knowledge of various resolves; and the power of knowledge of various realmsâ€”these four powers are all of the nature of nine knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation. That is to say, to know the intrinsic nature of the various meditations, etc., as they really are, is called the power of knowledge of the various meditations, etc.
The characteristics of the various meditations, etc., will be discussed in the chapter on samÄdhi.

If one knows, as they really are, the various kinds of sentient beings and the differences in their superior abilities and faculties without obstruction, this is called the power of knowledge of superior and inferior faculties.
Although there is a middling faculty, it is included in the inferior and superior faculties, so it is not separately manifested.
What is the meaning of the term â€œfacultyâ€ in this context?
It refers to faith, etc., in those who have severed the roots of goodness.
In the general continuity, there are also past and future. Faith and other good dharmas may refer to intention, etc.

If one truly knows the differences in the delight and understanding of sentient beings with unobstructed cognition, this is called the power of knowledge of various understandings, because delight and understanding are different names.

If one truly knows the various differences in the dispositions, proclivities, and natures of sentient beings that have been cultivated since beginningless time in the past with unobstructed cognition, this is called the power of knowledge of various natures.
One should know that here, nature, disposition, proclivity, and dharma nature are different names.
Thus, these four powers all take conditioned [dharmas] as objects, so among the ten knowledges, they only include nine knowledges.

The power of knowledge of the various paths and their respective destinations, or the term various indicates two meanings. If it is said that it only takes as objects the paths that lead to destinations, then it is nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation;
if it is said that it takes as objects both the paths that lead to destinations and the destinations that are reached by the paths, then it is ten knowledges.

That is to say, truly knowing the causes and effects of birth and death, and knowing the path to their cessation, with unobstructed cognition, is called the power of knowledge of the various paths and their respective destinations.
The eighth power is the knowledge of the recollection of past lives, and the ninth power is the knowledge of death and rebirth. These two powers are both by nature conventional knowledge.
These two powers have different characteristics. The eighth power is the unobstructed knowledge that truly knows the differences in past lives of oneself and others.
The ninth power is the unobstructed knowledge that truly knows the continuation of existence of all sentient beings in the future.
The extensive explanation of these two is like that in the section on the six supernatural powers.

The tenth power is the knowledge of the destruction of contamination. The word â€œpowerâ€ also indicates two meanings. If it is said that it only takes the destruction of contamination as its object, then it is six knowledges, excluding the knowledge of the path, suffering, accumulation, and the minds of others.
If it is said that it also takes the means of destroying contamination as its object, then it is ten knowledges by nature.

This is reasonable, because in the explanation of its characteristics, it says that the unobstructed knowledge regarding destruction and the means to destruction are both called the power of the knowledge of the destruction of contamination.

The last three powers are the three supernormal knowledges, because these three among the six supernormal knowledges are most excellent. In the state of post-learner, they are established as the three clear knowledges, and in the body of the TathÄgata, they are also called powers.
The supernormal knowledge of the divine eye and the divine ear, even in the Buddha's body, are not of great use, and therefore they are not called powers.

For example, the divine eye can see the differences in the karmic retribution of sentient beings in good and evil destinies, and because of this, it can induce the arising of superior knowledge. It also correctly understands the karma that can bring about those retributions. Because of this, the name of the supernormal knowledge of death and rebirth is established.
The supernormal knowledge of spiritual powers and the divine ear do not have this great use, and therefore those two are not established as powers.

However, the power of knowing the minds of others is not explained separately, because its meaning is already included in the powers of knowing faculties, etc., because among the faculties, etc. of others, there are minds and mental factors.

Moreover, the World-Honored One, endowed with omniscience, has mastery over crafts, treatises, and so forth. However, regarding the Buddha's work, this much is already accomplished. Other knowledges have no separate superior function within it. Therefore, although there is [omniscience], it is not separately mentioned. Only based on the universal awakening to the ten kinds of knowables, the Buddha's work is completely fulfilled.
What are called the ten kinds of knowables?

They are the meaning of causes and non-causes among all dharmas, the various distinctions of karmic results that are mostly scattered, the different types of merits and virtues in the stages of concentration, the differences in faculties, dispositions, and realms of sentient beings to be converted, the distinctions of causes and effects in what is to be countered and the counteragents, the differences in experiences in the past and future, the differences in skillful means for abandoning defilements and not continuing them. Merely by awakening to this, the Buddha's work is accomplished. Other existences, whether they exist or not, do not bring benefit or harm. Therefore, only the ten kinds are called powers.
Moreover, when the Buddha observes sentient beings to be converted, he establishes teachings in accordance with their capacities and only needs the ten knowledges.
That is, the first wisdom observes the differences in the capacities of those to be converted with regard to the vehicles.
The second wisdom observes the differences in karmic hindrances in the continuums of those to be converted.

The third wisdom observes the differences in the heavy and light hindrances of the passions with and without the flavor of the meditations, etc., of those to be converted. Knowing these two causes also means knowing the hindrances to maturation.
The fourth wisdom observes the differences in the capacities of those to be converted to enter the pure category.
The fifth wisdom observes the differences in the practices of those to be converted to enter the category of realization of the pure.
The sixth wisdom observes the differences in the various dispositions of those to be converted to enter the category of realization of the pure.
The seventh wisdom observes the various differences in the activities of those to be converted, whether beneficial or not, and correctly observes the cultivation of calming.
The eighth wisdom observes the differences in the accumulations of those to be converted in the past.
The ninth wisdom observes the differences in the future births of those to be converted.
The tenth power observes the differences in the skillful means for realizing liberation by those to be converted.
If any one of these ten knowledges is lacking, the work of converting sentient beings is not complete, and many are useless, so they are neither increased nor decreased.
The specific characteristics have been discussed.

As for the distinction of stages, the eighth and ninth powers are based on the four meditations, while the other eight are produced in eleven stages, namely, the four meditations, the intermediate state, and the four formless states, which are called the eleven stages. The stages of various superior qualities are all included in these.
As for the distinction of stages and bodies, all are based on the male body of the Buddha in JambudvÄ«pa, because only this body is capable of being the support of power.
The two vehicles also have these ten knowledges. Why are they only called powers in the Buddha?

The name power is given to the knowledge of the destruction of contamination because it turns without obstruction, because the Buddhaâ€™s knowledge turns without obstruction with regard to its object and therefore is named power. The knowledge of others is not so, because the two vehicles are unable to see the seeds of the roots of goodness that are favorable to liberation in the life streams of sentient beings, much less be able to know the other profound and subtle ones.

For example, ÅšÄriputra, when he was asked to save someone, was unable to see the number of lives of a pigeon being chased by a hawk, past and future, and MahÄmaudgalyÄyana was unable to see the differences in the ghosts attracted by the wind of karma. Therefore the two vehicles, with their divine eye and other forms of knowledge, are different from the Buddha in the distance and nearness of their vision of the realms of existence, because they are not without obstruction, and therefore they are not called powers.
Since the two vehicles and the Buddha are the same in the destruction of contamination, why is the knowledge of the Buddha alone called a power?
Only the World Honored One has the knowledge that thoroughly penetrates the specific characteristics of the destruction of contamination of all sentient beings.

The Bhagavat is unobstructed in the knowledge of the various categories of the extinction of all the passions of all sentient beings, but the two vehicles are not like this. Therefore, the name of the power belongs only to the Buddha.
Moreover, only the Buddhas have the power of wisdom that is sharp.
How is it sharp?
The power of the Buddha's wisdom can quickly eliminate afflictions and their habitual tendencies, like a strong person wielding a sharp knife to cut grass, etc.
The aggregates of all sentient beings are the same in appearance. How does the Buddha see that there are various realms?

Although the aggregates of all sentient beings are the same in appearance, there are still differences within them. That is to say, although the substance of those aggregates is not different, there are innumerable categories that are not the same. The Buddha knows them all as they are without obstruction. Therefore, the World-Honored One attains the power of the knowledge of various realms.

Or, the names of the TathÄgatas are lofty and far-reaching, with rare wisdom and wondrous functions boundless. Only the Buddha can know them, not something that others can fathom. Among the distinct characteristics that others understand, why should it be strange that the TathÄgata can know the distinct characteristics?
Having distinguished the extent of the Buddha's mental power, we should now distinguish the physical power that is also accomplished during the bodhisattva stage.

The physical power of the Great Awakened One, the Solitary Awakened One, and the Wheel-Turning King, connecting the parts of the body, are respectively like a dragon banner knot, like a chain of hooks. Therefore, the three are compared in terms of power, with superiority and inferiority.

That is, ordinary elephants, fragrant elephants, MahÄnÄga, PÄruá¹£aka, VÄraá¹‡agha, CÄá¹‡Å«ra, and NÄrÄyaá¹‡a, each subsequent power increases tenfold over the previous.

The celestial retinue numbers in the many thousands. Riding it, they soar through the sky like holding a birch leaf, and quickly reach the pleasure garden to enjoy themselves as they wish.

What are the distinctions of the four kinds of fearlessness of the Buddha?
Verse:
The four kinds of fearlessness are in order the first, twelfth, and seventh powers.
Treatise:
The four kinds of fearlessness of the Buddha are as extensively explained in the sutras.
The first fearlessness of perfect enlightenment has ten knowledges as its nature, just like the first power.
The second fearlessness of the complete destruction of defilements has sixty knowledges as its nature, like the tenth power.
The third fearlessness of explaining obstacles has eight knowledges as its nature, like the second power.
The fourth fearlessness of explaining the path of liberation has nine and ten knowledges as its nature, like the seventh power.
Why do the Buddhas have only four kinds of fearlessness?
But it is by means of these four that the TathÄgata manifests his own and othersâ€™ perfect virtues, and that he manifests his own and othersâ€™ perfect virtues in their entirety.

The first fearlessness manifests the perfect virtue of the knowledge of the Buddha himself; the second fearlessness manifests the perfect virtue of the elimination of passions of the Buddha himself. These two manifest the perfection of the virtue of benefit for himself.
In order to manifest the perfect virtue of benefit for others, the World Honored One again expounds the last two fearlessnesses.

The third fearlessness prevents one from entering the wrong path, and the fourth fearlessness causes one to enter the right path. That is to say, in various places the Buddha expounds the dharmas that are obstacles for disciples, causing them to eliminate them, which is to say, it is the expedient for cultivating the virtue of elimination.
Also, in various places he expounds the path of liberation for disciples, causing them to practice correctly, which is to say, it is the expedient for cultivating the virtue of knowledge.
These two manifest the perfection of the virtue of benefit for others.

But it is by means of these four, according to their respective functions, that the Buddha manifests his own and othersâ€™ perfect virtues of knowledge and elimination, and that he manifests his own and othersâ€™ perfect virtues in their entirety. Therefore only four kinds are established.
How can it be said that fearlessness is knowledge? It should be said that fearlessness is accomplished by knowledge.
In reality, this is so, but in order to show that fearlessness is the proximate cause of knowledge, therefore the substance of fearlessness is established on the basis of knowledge.
As for fearlessness, it means not being timid or fearful. Because one has knowledge, one is not timid or fearful of others, therefore knowledge can be the intrinsic nature of fearlessness.

Only the four wondrous knowledges of the Buddha are the causes of the four fearlessnesses. The wondrous knowledge of all dharmas and all characteristics of the TathÄgatas is the cause of the first fearlessness.
The wondrous knowledge of the TathÄgatas' elimination of all afflictions and habitual tendencies is the cause of the second fearlessness.
The wondrous knowledge of the TathÄgatas' knowledge of the benefits and harms of their disciples is the cause of the latter two fearlessnesses.

Or the substance of fearlessness is precisely the four wondrous knowledges. Timidity is called fear. It means being terrified due to not fully understanding the Dharma. Knowledge has the ability to directly treat this fear, and it is contrary to fear, therefore it is called fearlessness.
Is it not the case that the absence of ignorance is the substance of fearlessness? How can you say that the substance of knowledge is fearlessness?
This criticism is not correct. Knowledge is the proximate antidote of many dharmas, just as it is the absence of doubt.
That is, just as knowledge is the proximate antidote of ignorance, it also has the power to be the proximate antidote of fear, and therefore it is called knowledge and also fearlessness.
Just as it is the antidote of ignorance and also the antidote of doubt, it is therefore called knowledge and also certainty.
Although the object to be eliminated, ignorance, is not doubt, the absence of ignorance and the absence of doubt are called the same substance.
In the same way, although ignorance and fear are different, the name fearlessness refers to the substance of knowledge, because one good dharma can eliminate many bad dharmas.
Some say that ignorance also includes the substance of fear, so it should not be criticized here.
What is the difference between power and fearlessness?
There is no difference, because their substance is both knowledge.
However, the meaning of power is distinguished within the substance of knowledge, and fearlessness is established based on a different meaning.

The causes of not being subdued are called powers, and the causes of not being frightened are called fearlessnesses.ğŸ”½Or, the initial establishment is called power, and the non-movement after establishment is called fearlessness.
Or, the non-subjugation by others is called power, and the ability to subjugate others is called fearlessness.
Other masters say:
It is like a good doctor who thoroughly understands medical methods being called power, and skillfully curing various illnesses being called fearlessness.
Some say that being brave and strong is called power, and being courageous and unafraid is called fearlessness.
In this way, these two kinds also have different meanings. The meaning of accomplishing things is the meaning of power, and the meaning of not being timid is the meaning of fearlessness.
What are the characteristics of the Buddha's three establishments of mindfulness?
Verse:
The three establishments of mindfulness are mindfulness and wisdom, taking as objects the realms of what is favorable, unfavorable, and both.
Treatise:
The Buddha's three establishments of mindfulness are as extensively explained in the sutras.

When the disciples are all respectful and practice correctly, the TathÄgata, taking this as a condition, does not give rise to joy, but abandons it and abides peacefully in right mindfulness and right knowing. This is called the TathÄgata's first abiding in mindfulness.ğŸ”½When the disciples are all disrespectful and do not practice correctly, the TathÄgata, taking this as a condition, does not give rise to sorrow, but abandons it and abides peacefully in right mindfulness and right knowing. This is called the TathÄgata's second abiding in mindfulness.

When the disciples are of one kind, respectful and practicing correctly, and of another kind, disrespectful and not practicing correctly, the TathÄgata, taking this as a condition, does not give rise to joy or sorrow, but abandons it and abides peacefully in right mindfulness and right knowing. This is called the TathÄgata's third abiding in mindfulness.

Although there are those to be taught who are disrespectful and do not practice, the World-Honored Buddha still rains down the Dharma rain. Through this skillful means, at another time or for other sentient beings, they enter the true Dharma.

It is not the case that the four previously mentioned are now again said to be three, and therefore it can be said in general that there are seven foundations of mindfulness. The present three are included in the previous four, because they are included in the foundation of mindfulness of external dharmas.

However, these three kinds of foundations of mindfulness are by nature both mindfulness and wisdom, because one is born in the three realms through the establishment of correct mindfulness and correct discernment, and one does not generate joy or sorrow.

It is impossible for any great disciples to not generate joy or sorrow in the three realms, and therefore it cannot be said that these three kinds are not attributes exclusive to a Buddha. They are only eliminated by a Buddha, because he thoroughly understands the differences in the natures of sentient beings.

Or, the disciples are followers of the TathÄgata, and it would be very strange if he were to generate joy, sorrow, or both in regard to them. The Buddha is able not to generate them, and this can be called extraordinary. If the disciples do not generate them, it is not extraordinary, and therefore they are only found in a Buddha and are called attributes exclusive to a Buddha.
What are the characteristics of the great compassion of all Buddhas?
Verse:
Great compassion is only conventional knowledge, with provisions, aspects, and objects,
Because of equality and the highest level, compassion is distinguished by eight causes.
The treatise says:

The great compassion of the TathÄgata has conventional wisdom as its nature, universally taking as its object all sentient beings, because it takes on the three aspects of the suffering of suffering, etc. Pure wisdom does not have this principle.
On what meaning is the name of this great compassion established?
For five meanings, this is established as great.
First, because of the accumulation, it is great. It is accomplished by the accumulation of great merit and wisdom.
Second, because of the aspect, it is great. It is able to take the three kinds of suffering as its object and take on their aspects.
Third, because of the object, it is great. It universally takes the sentient beings of the three realms as its object.
Fourth, because of equality, it is great. It equally benefits and brings happiness to all sentient beings.
Fifth, because of the highest level, it is great. There is no other compassion that can equal it.
Other masters say:

It is called great compassion because it is realized through great effort, it is accomplished by the body of a great person, it is included among the great treasures of merit, and it is able to save sentient beings from great suffering.
What is the difference between compassion and great compassion?
There are eight differences between these two.
First, there is a difference in essence, because the essence of compassion is absence of hatred and absence of delusion.
Second, there is a difference in the bodies in which they exist, because compassion exists in the bodies of others, but great compassion exists only in the body of a Buddha.
Third, there is a difference in their aspects, because compassion has the three aspects of suffering, while great compassion has the four aspects of suffering.
Fourth, there is a difference in their objects, because compassion has the three realms as objects, while great compassion has the one realm as object.

Fifth, there is a difference in the stages in which they exist, because compassion exists in the fourth trance state and also in other stages, while great compassion exists only in the fourth trance state.

Sixth, there is a difference in the way they are realized, because compassion is realized by detachment from the summit of existence, while great compassion is realized by detachment from the summit of the material world.
Moreover, compassion is realized at the time of detachment, and great compassion is realized only at the time of detachment.

Seventh, there is a difference in the fulfillment of the hope of saving, because compassion fulfills the hope of saving by means of the three vehicles, while great compassion fulfills the hope of saving by means of the one vehicle.
The eighth is due to the equality or inequality of compassion.
Other masters say:

The great compassion of the Buddhas is far-reaching, subtle, and all-pervading, and is able to universally benefit. The compassionate minds produced by Å›rÄvakas and others are unable to have compassion for the form and formless realms. The Buddhas have the utmost compassion for the upper realms, surpassing the compassion of the two vehicles for the AvÄ«ci Hell.
The differences in the merits of the Buddhas from other sentient beings have already been explained.
Are the dharmas of the Buddhas equal to each other when compared with each other?
The verse states:
Due to the provisions, the Dharma body, and benefiting others, the Buddhas are similar.
Life span, lineage, nature, and size, the Buddhas have differences.
The commentary states:

The Buddhas are all equal due to three things: first, due to the equality of the provisions being fully perfected; second, due to the equality of the Dharma body being accomplished; and third, due to the equality of benefiting others being ultimate.
The Buddhas have differences when compared with each other due to the differences in life span, lineage, nature, and body size.

Life span is different, because the life span of buddhas is short or long. Family is different, because buddhas are born in the ká¹£atriya or brÄhman class. Surname is different, because buddhas have the surnames Gautama, KÄÅ›yapa, and so on. Size is different, because buddhas have small or large bodies.

The word â€œetc.â€ indicates that there are differences in the length of time the Dharma of buddhas remains in the world, and so on. This is because the capacities of sentient beings to be converted differ when buddhas appear in the world.
The three kinds of perfect virtues of the TathÄgata are to be deeply loved and respected by the wise.
What are the three?
First, the perfect virtue of causes; second, the perfect virtue of effects; third, the perfect virtue of kindness.
The first, the perfect virtue of causes, is also of four kinds:
First, cultivation without remainder, because the two kinds of provisions of merit and wisdom are cultivated without omission.
Second, cultivation for a long time, because cultivation lasts for three incalculably long eons without weariness.
Third, uninterrupted cultivation, because diligent and vigorous cultivation is uninterrupted moment by moment.
Fourth, respectful cultivation, because cultivation without regard for anything else is done without arrogance.
Next, the virtues of perfect fruition are also of four kinds:
1. The virtue of wisdom, 2. the virtue of severance, 3. the virtue of power, and 4. the virtue of the physical body.
The virtue of wisdom is of four kinds:
1. The wisdom without a teacher, 2. the wisdom of all things, 3. the wisdom of all modes, and 4. effortless wisdom.
The virtue of severance is of four kinds:
1. The severance of all passions, 2. the severance of all obstacles to samÄdhi, 3. the severance that is absolute, and 4. the severance that is also of habitual propensities.
The virtue of power is of four kinds:

1. The power of mastery over the transformation, continuation, and support of external objects, 2. the power of mastery over the shortening or lengthening of one's life span, 3. the power of mastery over the small and large entering into each other, and over the extremely distant and rapid movement through space and matter, 4. the power of causing the various natures of the world to turn and become ever more excellent and marvelous.
The virtue of power is also of four kinds:

First, they can definitely transform those who are difficult to transform; second, they can definitely resolve doubts by answering difficult questions; third, they can definitely establish teachings that lead to liberation; fourth, they can definitely subdue evil factions.
The physical body has four kinds of perfect virtues:
First, being endowed with the major marks;
Second, being endowed with the minor marks;
Third, being endowed with great strength;
Fourth, the bones of the inner body are stronger than vajra;
The divine light emitted externally surpasses that of a hundred thousand suns.

The four kinds of perfect virtues of grace are: causing beings to be permanently liberated from the three evil destinies and birth and death, or being able to establish them in the good destinies and the three vehicles.
The perfect virtues of the TathÄgata are explained in general like this.

If analyzed separately, there are infinitely many. Only the World-Honored Buddha can know and explain them. If he were to remain in the world for many great eons, speaking for an incalculably long time, he could exhaust them.
This shows that the body of the World-Honored Buddha is endowed with infinitely many supreme, wondrous, and special causes, effects, and virtues, like a great jeweled mountain.

There are foolish people who lack many virtues themselves, and even though they hear such a mountain of the Buddha's merits and the Dharma he expounds, they are unable to give rise to faith and respect.
Those who are wise, upon hearing such teachings, give rise to a mind of faith and respect that penetrates to the bone marrow.
Because of this single thought of utmost faith and respect, they extinguish boundless indeterminate evil karma, and embrace the most excellent human, heavenly, and nirvÄá¹‡a destinies.

Therefore it is said that the TathÄgata's appearance in the world is the unsurpassed field of merit for the wise, because relying on it one gives rise to results that are not empty, desirable, most excellent, swift, and ultimate.
As the Blessed One himself said in a verse:
If one can plant even a small amount of goodness in the Buddha's field of merit,
One will first attain the excellent destinies, and later will surely attain nirvÄá¹‡a.
